node.text:
What does it mean to be cold-blooded in Glacier? In Part 1, we explored the icy streams at the top of the continent, the creatures that depend on them for survival, and how the effects of warming temperatures trickle down. 

In Part 2, we’re down much lower, in McGee Creek in the North Fork part of the park. Researchers here are looking at native Westslope Cutthroat Trout. They’re trying to determine how the changes in stream flow and stream temperature that we’ve been seeing are affecting these cold-water adapted fish. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #ClimateChange #AquaticEcology

node.title: Science Friday - Taking the Pulse of the Landscape, Part 2

node.text:
What does it mean to be cold-blooded in Glacier? Does anything really live in the most frigid waters in the park? 

Join us for the first of a special two-part series exploring the park’s aquatic ecosystems and how they’re changing – starting with the icy streams at the very top of the continent. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #ClimateChange #AquaticEcology

node.title: Science Friday: Taking the Pulse of the Landscape, Part 1

node.text:
Feel like you need some space? No need to planet out. Just watch this week’s Science Friday video! 

To celebrate our recent full certification as an International Dark Sky Park from the International Dark Sky Association @idadarksky, we went to talk to Glacier’s lead astronomy educator and east side interpreter, Lee Rademaker. 

Lee has been instrumental in bringing astronomy programming to park visitors, both in-person and online. We went over to the Dusty Star Observatory in St. Mary to learn about how the observatory works, why dark skies are important, and how we can stay connected to Glacier’s night skies from near and far. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #Astronomy #Space #Telescope #NightSkies #DarkSkies

node.text:
Mountains are memorable, but chances are good that if you’ve visited Glacier, you’ve enjoyed some of the gorgeous grasslands on the park’s east side. You may have stopped at one to photograph wildflowers or watch a grizzly bear. A good example is in St. Mary, which you can view on this webcam. 

Prior to the establishment of the park, Native Americans followed bison across these grasslands, using traditional ecological knowledge to maintain a highly diverse and intact biome. Over the past century, the park’s grasslands have been impacted by settlement, livestock grazing, park and concessioner development, noxious weed invasion, and change in fire regimes. 

In 1999, park ecologists established 155 permanent vegetation monitoring plots in 99 different meadows. 

For this week’s Science Friday, we had the chance to go out with the botany crew. They’re spending the summer surveying those plots established 20 years ago to evaluate how the vegetation has changed. What changes do you think you might see? 

#sciencefriday #glaciernationalpark #parkscience #botany #wildflowers #ecology #climatechange

node.title: Science Friday - The Grasslands, They Are A-Changin'

node.text:
This video will help you prepare for using the recreation.gov mobile site to purchase a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket. Tickets are limited and can sell out before you get one even if you are prepared, but knowing how to use the site puts you in the best position to successfully acquire one.

To learn more about ticketed entry visit our website, https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm.

node.text: On Science Friday this week, we learn all about the loon banding project happening here in Northwest Montana. We then get to go out--at night--to bring you a firsthand look at what it takes to capture and band loons! #ScienceFriday #ParkScience #wildlifebio

node.text:
Glacier National Park is classified as a Class 1 airshed under the Clean Air Act. This designation affords the highest level of air quality protection provided under the Act. 

Fresh air, dramatic views, and pristine water are some of the qualities that draw visitors to Glacier from all over the world. Air quality in the park affects obvious things, like visibility. It also has less obvious impacts - on water quality, forest composition and ecosystem function. 

Glacier has had a permanent air quality monitoring site since 1980. The site includes devices and networks that measure different components of the atmosphere. 

Join us for this Science Friday, as the park's Physical Scientist shows us around the site and explains how we measure air quality in Glacier! 

#ScienceFriday #ScienceInParks #GlacierNationalPark #ParkScience #AirQuality

node.title: Science Friday- What's in the Air?

node.text:
You probably expect that Glacier protects things like bears and rivers. Did you know, though, that the park also protects and preserves over 700 historic structures?

Welcome back to Season Two of Science Fridays with Ranger Melissa! We are so excited to continue exploring, learning, and discovering science and research in the park with you! 
This week, we learn about historic buildings in Glacier from the park's historical architect, Kim Hyatt.

node.title: Science Friday - Historic Buildings of Glacier

node.text:
Have you missed us? Science Friday with Ranger Melissa is back with a great final Science Friday video for you! This week, Melissa goes out with John Waller, the park’s bear biologist, to explore the trail for signs of bears, discover differences between bears in Glacier and elsewhere, and learn about how bears live at different times of year. 

#ParkScience #ScienceFriday #Bears #Hibernation #GlacierNationalPark #WildlifeBiology #ScienceInParks

node.title: Science Friday - Glacier's Bears with John Waller

node.text: This week, we are bringing you a VERY special Science Friday. Ranger Melissa travels to an active archaeological site on the east side of the park to meet with archaeologist Brent Rowley. A river has been eroding away the bank, revealing some incredible things about the history of this place. Watch more to find out what they discover! #sciencefriday #parkscience #archaeology #scienceinparks #glaciernationalpark

node.text:
What does it mean to be cold-blooded in Glacier? In Part 1, we explored the icy streams at the top of the continent, the creatures that depend on them for survival, and how the effects of warming temperatures trickle down. 

In Part 2, we’re down much lower, in McGee Creek in the North Fork part of the park. Researchers here are looking at native Westslope Cutthroat Trout. They’re trying to determine how the changes in stream flow and stream temperature that we’ve been seeing are affecting these cold-water adapted fish. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #ClimateChange #AquaticEcology

node.accessibility_caption: Black-and-white photo showing a lake surrounded by snow-covered mountains and trees.

node.text:
Ever wonder what the Many Glacier valley looked like before the hotel and other buildings were constructed? This photo taken by Fred Kiser around 1911 gives us some idea.

Construction on the Many Glacier Hotel began in 1914, but before that there was a small mining boom in the area that peaked around 1898-1900. Tales of great mineral wealth in the Swiftcurrent Valley had attracted a flurry of miners and settlers searching for copper, oil, and other minerals, but little to nothing of these were ever found and most claims, but for a few holdouts, lay abandoned by 1903.

After Glacier National Park was established in 1910, the Great Northern Railway started building visitor accommodations along Swiftcurrent Lake in the form of teepee camps and smaller chalets, followed by the opening of the Many Glacier Hotel in 1915. As a result, the surrounding mountains, such as Mt. Gould and Grinnell Point (shown here), look down on a different landscape today than they did in 1911. #tbt #throwbackthursday

node.text:
Have you ever worn a uniform? 

For NPS Fashion Week, we're turning our attention to the iconic Ranger uniform. Designed 100 years ago, the Ranger uniform has remained largely unchanged ever since (for men, at least). Women in the NPS have encountered varying uniform expectations, including skirts, pumps, and a lack of a "stetson" hat requirement.

No matter which NPS site you visit, you'll always see the uniform. Flat hats and pleated pants, an enduring tradition brought to life each day by park staff—although sometimes "tradition" doesn't keep up with the latest breathable fabrics and modern materials.

To learn more about the history of the now-iconic ranger uniform, visit the NPS' Uniform Collection online, here: https://www.nps.gov/subjects/hfc/nps-uniform-collection.htm

#NPSFW #GreenAndGray #GreenAndGrayHeretoStay

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on September 12, 2021. May be an image of mountain and nature.

node.text:
Looking for recommendations on where to hike in Glacier National Park? Staff at our visitor centers and ranger stations can help, but deciding a few things ahead of time can truly streamline the planning process: 

First, how many miles do you want to hike? Knowing your capabilities is essential. A trail that’s easy for some visitors may be very challenging for others. Thinking through the mileage and elevation change that you’re comfortable with can help us find the right trails for you. 

Second, in which part of the park will you be? Glacier encompasses about 1,600 square miles. Drive time from one area to another may be several hours. For example, Many Glacier has some spectacular trail options for hikers of all abilities, but getting there from West Glacier requires a 3-hour drive. If your schedule doesn’t allow for longer drives, you’ll want to ask about hikes closer to where you are. 

Third, what do you want to see on your hike? Wildlife,  glaciers, forests, alpine lakes, wildflowers, mountain peaks, waterfalls...? With over 700 miles of trails, Glacier  National Park has something for every hiker–from novice to expert. Sharing your interests can help us help you find what you’re seeking. 

Answering these three questions can help our rangers quickly recommend a “just-right” hike for any visitor. Additionally, you can check out our website for trail maps and safety reminders.

Image: a hiker on a mountainous trail.

node.accessibility_caption:
A photo of Mount Cleveland and the goat haunt valley superimposed behind the New York City Skyline, pre-9/11,

On-screen text: "In today's world, remote areas like Goat Haunt are impacted by events and circumstances far removed from park boundaries.

Photos: Mount Cleveland from Goat Haunt, Glacier National Park; New York City and the World Trade Center."

node.text:
Today, we remember 9/11.

Glacier National Park, along with Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, is an International Peace Park—separated by a 20-foot swath between the two nations. Glacier’s northernmost entrance, Goat Haunt, is primarily accessed by traveling through Canada, then into the US by boat (requiring a passport).

The events of 9/11 took place far from Montana—but its impact was felt everywhere, even in Glacier's most remote regions.

Pictured here is a wayside exhibit installed in Goat Haunt after 9/11, superimposing the New York City skyline beneath Mount Cleveland in Goat Haunt. The sign remembers the tragedy and recognizes its far-reaching effects.

“…Goat Haunt seems an oasis of solitude and tranquility, a place seemingly untouched by the frenetic pace of the city and the complex problems of the wider world.

The events of September 11, 2001 brought sudden change to Goat Haunt. Tremors from these shocking acts of terrorism were felt along this peaceful stretch of boundary as the United States responded to homeland security threats. This once open border crossing, where people from all nations could travel between countries with minimal scrutiny, was suddenly closed… The world's first international peace park was a less peaceful place as the hard realities of the world overshadowed the ideals of cooperation and collaboration shared here between nation friends.

The events of September 11 were a stark reminder that harmony and friendship are fragile commodities in a world where intolerance and war are such common responses.

Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park is still a powerful setting for personal reflection on peace, what it means, and how our perspectives might be influenced by world events… This Peace Park, managed cooperatively and spanning two nations, reminds us of the possibilities of international goodwill and friendship so needed in our fragile world today.”

node.accessibility_caption: A group of people stand on a dock next to a wooden tour boat on Swiftcurrent Lake with mountains in the distance.

node.text:
Matinee gloves, floral dresses, brooches, double breasted suits, sweater vests, hats tipped at a jaunty angle. You might think that’s proper attire for a day on the town, but in the past it’s what some people would wear when visiting a national park like Glacier. 

This photo was likely taken in the early 1940s by photographer John Kabel as a promotional image commissioned by the Great Northern Railway. We don’t know who these people were, but they clearly knew how to travel in style.

These days, those who take the same boat tour on Swiftcurrent Lake in Many Glacier are more likely to see puffy jackets, scuffed hiking boots, and convertible hiking pants, but appreciation of Glacier’s charms likely remains constant no matter what one wears.

Whose style in this photo is your favorite?

#NPSFW #ThrowbackThursday #tbt

node.accessibility_caption: A light brown ground squirrel stands on its hind legs, using its front paws to bring blades of grass and seeds to its mouth.

node.text:
Seen one of these around lately? Maybe you have, maybe you haven’t… 

Columbian ground squirrels live throughout the park in grasslands and meadows, and they’re a common sight during the summer months. But they hibernate most of the year, starting…right about now!

Sometimes these animals will start hibernating as early as July, staying underground for 7-9 months before emerging in the spring. We’ve still seen a few out and about this past week though. Keep an eye out for these squirrels—their absence is a sure sign that fall is around the corner.

node.accessibility_caption: A subalpine meadow at sunset, with trees in the foreground and mountains in the background.

node.text:
Happy Labor Day!⁣
⁣
Glacier is a place where many come to get away from work—but this park depends on the labor of countless volunteers, staff, park partners, community members, and visitors⁣.
⁣
Clearing trails, offering guided hikes, studying wildlife, fixing leaky pipes, surveying archaeological sites, responding to emergencies, running campgrounds, protecting native plants, serving meals, driving shuttles… it’s a lot of work!⁣
⁣
To everyone who works to protect Glacier: thank you, and happy #labordayweekend

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on September 05, 2021. May be an image of lake, tree and nature.

node.text:
Glacier National Park is frequently overcrowded, even after Labor Day. Ever wonder what other adventures await just outside the park? Breathtaking views and great outdoor recreation don’t simply stop at Glacier’s boundaries, and you can easily plan parts of your trip to avoid crowds and take advantage of all this area has to offer. 

Many folks visiting here for several days also explore the surrounding public lands, rather than just Glacier itself. The Middle and North Forks of the Flathead River make up the boundary between the national park and Flathead National Forest, where hiking and camping options are plentiful. Along the extensive Hungry Horse Reservoir, visitors can go fishing, take a dip, rent watercraft, hang out on shore, or camp at campgrounds operated by the US Forest Service. 

Others might choose to spend some time at the wonderful state parks in the area, like Lone Pine State Park west of Kalispell. Staying in Whitefish during your trip? Les Mason and Whitefish Lake State Parks are very close by. Or maybe you’re staying near Bigfork? A day spent exploring Flathead Lake is well worthwhile. 

To find out more about amenities and opportunities in US National Forests or Montana State Parks, please visit their respective websites, and enjoy all that this scenic region has to offer! 

Image description: A reflective river in the mountains before sunset.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on September 04, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
As the days grow shorter and temperatures get cooler, what kinds of autumn foods do you crave? Maybe some hot soup or pumpkin pie? 🍂🥧

Just as we humans love tasty fall treats, some animals in Glacier also enjoy finding lots of food during the autumn season. Two species of rather frenzied fall foragers are our bears. As summer draws to a close, bears enter a stage biologists call hyperphagia, which simply means “super-eating.” In the months just before hibernation, they’re more active, spending much more time and energy foraging. Since they typically don’t eat during hibernation, they need to pack on plenty of pounds before winter! 

It’s always important to store food properly when visiting bear country. Keep food and other scented items in secure bear boxes located in campgrounds or inside a locked vehicle. While backcountry camping, use designated bear boxes or bring a rope to hang your pack and food on a bear hang. 

While it’s illegal to feed animals in the park, it is safe (and a good idea!) to carry snacks or lunch with you while hiking. But never leave any food unattended, as bears or other wildlife can easily sniff out your snacks, and human food isn’t healthy for them. Additionally, an animal that becomes food-conditioned can be extremely dangerous and may need to be euthanized. 

Storing food properly not only protects us, it also helps keep our wildlife wild, both now and into the future! 

Image description: A brown-colored black bear nestled in vegetation.

What does it mean to be cold-blooded in Glacier? Does anything really live in the most frigid waters in the park? 

Join us for the first of a special two-part series exploring the park’s aquatic ecosystems and how they’re changing – starting with the icy streams at the very top of the continent. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #ClimateChange #AquaticEcology

UPDATE: Jennifer Coleman, who was reported missing Wednesday, September 1, was found deceased in a steep and rocky area near the Continental Divide. 

Cause of death is currently under investigation. 

GNP would like to thank the public for their response to the tip line. 

————————————————————————

Glacier National Park is seeking the public’s help in locating Jennifer (Jenn) Coleman.

She is believed to have been hiking around Logan Pass on 8/30 or 8/31. Coleman is 5’6” with blond, shoulder length hair and blue eyes. She was most likely hiking in an outfit like the one pictured (left). 

If you saw Jenn Coleman in Glacier National Park, please call the Glacier National Park tip line at 406-888-7077.
